values: Someday you will see this all in context of a life worth living.

I really don't know what to say to you. 

Life is unexpected. You will learn and never stop learning from the choices you make. This is a new beginning, albeit a lonely and scary one. There may be times that you lose sight of what lies ahead and you may not even want to go on to meet it. But in the end I can't tell you what to do or what to think or what to believe. So I will not dictate nor will I judge.

Just remember you are loved. And that, despite the distance, is the best thing I can give you.

But you knew that already.

Hello Livejournal. It's nice to see you again.

---

You know what I miss? I miss being Filipino. You see, it's like this: America is beautiful. America teaches you to stand on your own two feet and be your own person. It teaches you how to not take crap and smile like nothing happened. It takes you for a ride, in one of it's 2008 Mercedes S-class sedans, Chris Brown blaring on your stereo hooked up to your i-pod while you laugh and scream on your bluetooth i-phone.

But you see, as many a thing America can possibly teach you, it doesn't know about where you came from. Sure you'll go to that cultural festival, but that little child singing, "Bayang magiliw, Perlas ng sinananaaaang!!" will not be singing it that way to be droll. And the people in the audience will not clap in delight because they know her lyrics are adorably erroneous but because oh! That child sings Tagalog songs so well! It's so nice to see parents teaching their children their beloved culture!

Because here, you will buy that $6 bottle of Palmolive coconut shampoo, and you will go to that sad place that passes itself for Jollibee with their sad, sad Chicken Joy and gravy, and you will get that t-shirt with Manny Pacquiao's face benevolently surveying that limp Philippine flag tied haphazardly onto that flagpole bearing the American flag.

Because you have to. And because you have no choice.

Because this place, America, is about adapting.

It's about turning your scathing, over-analytic, ethnocentric eyes away from the revelry that becomes carnage in your mind because that is how you want to see it.

But damn, I still want my Chicken Joy.

I saw someone who looked like you.

I saw someone who looked like you.

I saw someone who looked like you.

I saw someone who looked like you.



And I kinda remembered. 



But not that much.

Ako. Wala na akong maramdaman. Puro iwas, sa araw-araw (araw-araw-araw) na
Buhay? Yun ata ang tawag nila dun. Winala na ata ni Oras. Si Ako.

Huminga ka man, tatlong higup ng hangin. Huwag ka nang pipikit. Tapos.
Hihilain ka nila pabalik. (Sayang daw ang liwanag, nandiyan na ang dilim)

Matatawa ka na lang. Nang walang dahilan.
Hahalakhak ka. Hahalakhak. (Haha-ha-ha-lak-hak).
Para 'di ka nila pa-iisipin. Itago mo lang 
May dugo pa bang umaagos sa iyong katawan?





(erm, to be continued.. napudpod na ko... sa uulitin)

Like damn, man.

Gabby had an operation last week and today we learned she has thyroid cancer. Granma Luz had it and its scary that I might get it too. Mom is going crazy because of it and has eliminated sodas and adding blueberries and naked juice to the shopping list.

And I'm sick because I've been doing overtime this whole week. Damn.

And, and... status quo is in the top two! WTF man. W-T-F.

In happier news, Alaine is having her debut on April 5 so woohoo!

Plus today in the bank guess who I saw... Marcia Cross from Desperate Hosewives. I could've helped her out if I wasn't stuck with another customer. Gah.

In the spirit of UP Fair month... ta-dah! Ha ha. Kakamiss. Happy valentine's folks!



Gawrd, what I'd give to be that thin again. LOLZ.

I don't write simply because I do not have anything to write about. What drives me to write is, for lack of a better term, teenage angst. 

I think teenage angst has more to do with the weird (supposedly small) things we concern ourselves with like feeling as if we were the center of the universe and heartbreak and nasty clique wars, and less to do with being over twelve and under twenty (because after all, you can still think you're the center of the universe when you turn twenty-one).

Less than a year out of college and I think my supply in teenage angst is running low.

I miss writing things that have more to do with my neverending process of mending myself after every fall and less about how much I spent on overpriced shoes.

I miss my teenage angst.



I'm hoping it's just on sabbatical.

I voted for Clinton. If she wins it'd be so awesome because when I'm sixty-five I can take my teeny grandchildren aside and say, 

"Alam nyo ba, isa ako sa mga bumoto sa pinaka-unang babaeng presidente ng Amerika! Aha ha ha. Mga Amerikano talaga, ano? Tagal-tagal pa bago nagkaroon ng babaeng leader. Ayan tuloy, tagal din bago gumanda ang pamamalakad ng gobyerno nila."

Ha ha ha.

But I don't think it would go that way. Di ko naman kasi ginagamit yung mga salitang pamamalakad at gobyerno.


La lang.

"What can I help you with today sir?"
"Oh just a deposit."
"Alright." Take slip and checks, enter amount, validate receipt...

"My son's friend died today."
"Oh goodness. I'm so sorry. What happened?" What the..? Like I care, old man. Move on.
"Not quite sure. He's in New York." Blah blah blah blah.
"Will you be going to New York for the funeral then?"
"No, my son is there though. Keith Ledger...?"
"Oh."
"Yeah, he's a young actor. You know, the one in that cowboy movie..."
"Heath Ledger?"
"Heath, yeah that's him."


Holy shit.



NOOOOOO!!!!

I saw her a day before and there she was again today, across the street, sitting on the plastic bus stop bench. The 9:45 came and went but there she still sat, her gray hair pinned up, her back straight, her hands folded neatly in her lap.

I watched her, her eyes and her poise unwavering. 

The 10 o' clock bus came and she stood up, frantically scanning the faces of the people filing out the door. A minute passed, the small crowd disappeared as suddenly as it appeared. 

And all that was left of the scurry was the gray-haired lady, standing there with the expectant smile on her face fading quickly away.

"Waiting for someone?" I called to her, wanting to know what she was waiting for.

I seemed to have startled her for a moment but then she smiled,

"Yes. But it's taking a bit longer than I expected." She straightened her back, smoothed her palm across her hair.
And with a final nod towards my direction she began walking away. 

I knew she would be back again tomorrow.

Creepy French man climbs out of car and walks toward unsuspecting girl in brown coat.  
Creepy French man introduces himself, Girl smiles tentatively wondering if Creepy French Man is one of the bank customers. 
Creepy French Man offers free haircut mentioning he is a hairstylist. 
Creepy French Man says Girl most likely has a boyfriend. 
Girl laughs uneasily and says that yes, she is in fact taken. 
Creepy French Man says they should have lunch sometime as friends. 
Girl smiles and says "Sure," while thinking, "Hell no." 
Creepy French Man gives Girl his card and says she should call sometime. 
Girl smiles and says "Sure," while thinking, "Hell no." 
Creepy French Man makes Girl promise. 
Girl smiles and says "Sure," while walking rapidly towards the safety of the bank. 


---- 


Rabin got hit on by a customer. A guy customer. But that's another story.

California storms are amateur but enough to warrant panic from these American weaklings. And enough to knock out the power for more than five minutes. I can't remember the last time I ever needed candles. 

Sunday, mom and Aliah and I went to the valley to take advantage of Ate Awit's 50% employee discount at Wild Pair. In the mall we passed by M.A.C. and since we were dying for some semblance of good makeup we took the plunge. A $130 plunge. Crap. Their makeup is great but I do not know why the hell I spent so much on M.A.C. considering that I am not rich and that I am supposed to be saving up for a whole lotta grown-up crap.

Car payments. Insurance. My frikin toric contact lens for astigmatism. Rent. Groceries. Credit card payments. Shoes.


(Aisha pops an anurism and dies while waiting for the power to go up...)


I can't believe how hanidicapped I am right now without the frikin lights.

2007 has been an amazing year. So much has changed; my home, my priorities, people, places, faces... It's hard to even keep up sometimes.  

I often ask myself how in the world have I ended up in the here and now. And almost always, I don't even have the answer.  

A year ago, I could have sworn against life that I would never become a slave to the corporate world. A year ago, I could have sworn against heaven that the moment I stepped off Philippine soil, I could not possibly move on. A year ago, I could have sworn against everything that my life wouldn't be much different than the last twenty years of my life.  

It's crazy how God works but I guess He knows what He is doing. 


2007 meant new stress in the form of student theses. 
2007 meant being able to survive Avecilla. 
2007 meant graduation, and moving on into the real world even when we weren't ready. 
2007 meant Thailand. 
2007 meant Majesthy and Chrisie. 
2007 meant moving away. 
2007 meant forgetting to make amends. 
2007 meant being emo. 
2007 meant finding my family again after 14 years. 
2007 meant football games and pyrotechnics. 
2007 meant Jose Rizal and the body of Christ. 
2007 meant free roses. 
2007 meant UP Balicas. 
2007 meant Heroes. 
2007 meant Terri's. 
2007 meant tunnel wishes. 
2007 meant fishitarianism. 
2007 meant twins, a boy and girl.  
2007 meant Tagaytay.
2007 meant Dencio's.
2007 meant Cineastes Anonymous. 
2007 meant sunshine and duckies.

2007 meant letting go. 

--- 

Happy 2008, my duckies. I love you.

Mom and Auntie Alice have been cleaning and cooking since forever and the place is spotless. And so come the Bagamaspads in all their glory; boyfriends, food and Jack Daniels the dog in tow. It's a wonder how you could actually fit 40 people in this house at any one time. But hey, nothing can't be done.

I got a teddy from The Alaines, fluffy slippers from J and A, chocolate and more chocolate and chocolate covered chocolate from the customers from work, Ross actually bought us a microwave (yay!) in defiance to Auntie Alice's refusal to let microwaves invade her house; Aliah got me these really cool shoes that I knew she was going to get me anyway, and Awit got me pair of killer heels (haha, i get it!).

I missed these kind of Christmases, and not only because of the presents but I really missed out on all the good family crap. LOL.

Anyway.

Happy Holidays duckies.


--- 

Let's kick it old school.

I'm going crazy.


Like, for real.


Christmas shopping is madness this late in the month. Stupid me putting it off like I put everything else.

Tomorrow the office is having a Christmas dinner at the Promenade. I went to buy Henry's gift at the mall about an hour ago and everyone was there. And you could see the panic in their eyes. For real. It'll be worse starting tomorrow no doubt.

And our customers keep bringing us chocolates and candy and cake and holiday treats and it's just crazy.

Ryan Seacrest on KIIS 102.7 said that the average American gains 6 pounds between Thanksgiving and New Year's. Ohmeegah..

Halp.

Having too much fun. Ahahahahahah. Saturday night out with Jennifer and Aliah and friends, trying to hook me up with some dude named Borda.

Sunday shopping at the L.A. Fashion District, and Oh My Gah... All I can say is 5 dollar handbags, 8 dollar newsboy caps and real mexicano food from the street... Heaven.

And a midnight drive to Toys R Us with the cousins.

Monday, and I'm beat.


---


Mmm, fruity.

Starbucks chismis: Turrell the Starbucks guy came to the bank and told us about one this one guy who also works at Starbucks who has been apprehended for the Malibu fire. Holy crap. Imagine getting your coffee everyday from a guy who burned down 50 houses and caused 15 thousand predominantly rich people to evacuate their homes.

Imagine being Schwarzenegger getting your coffee from the guy who burned down part of your beloved California.

Tsk.


---

I finally caught the governor at Starbucks today. In shorts. In December. In the frikin cold. It's so cold that yesterday, I found Monster's windshield covered in frost. Cold cold COLD. Ahahahah. Arnold Schwarzenegger is our governor.

Dyowskopow.


---


I need to go holiday shopping really soon. And go watch Sweeney Todd.

I got to help out Bonnie Hunt at the bank. Yay. But no free coffee today. Boo.

I can't wait until Sunnershiner and Ace come back from college for the holidays. Yay, Christmas at Disneyland!

Naalala ko ang mga ilaw sa UP pag krismas. Ahay, andun pa ba ang mga puting parol sa Palma Hall? Holy crabcakes, ano na nga ba ang tawag sa Palma Hall?? Nyemes.


---

Would you be my "it's complicated"?



Panalo.


---


Apparently, brain-death lasts more than 24 hours. Hello, week. It's sad that I don't have my Heroes to look forward to on Mondays. Stupid Mondays.

We bought a tree for the living room. I'm such a hypocrite, decorating my beautiful tree and still wanting to save the world... pffbbt.

Yesterday, I was so brain-dead that I had to go to sleep by the time I dragged my feet though the door of the house. At 8:30. At eight-friggin-thirty. God, I am beginning to hate fridays. On the other hand, I still love shopping.

Last weekend, I went shopping with Mom and Uncle Andre and his wife Auntie Let. It was quite the family affair. In the mile that was Thousand Oaks, parked in neat rows as far as the eye could see...

From Camrys to Mini Coopers, Beetles to Priuses, Civics, Jeeps, GTs and CR-Vs...

Four-doors, two-doors, coupes, sedan LEs; 4-wheel, horsepowered, 6-disc, SYNCed...

The Car Mall.

The wonderful, magnificent, omnipumpillescent Car Mall.

From corner to corner we scoured, comparing notes and milage and MPGs.

Minutes passed.

Hours passed.

And in the end we emerged victorious. Bone-tired but oh so victorious.


Introducing...




MONSTER. My sweet little Mazda 3.

I had a good day today.

First good thing that happened to me today was that I got a free eggnog latte from Starbucks. So when my sister dropped me off too early for work, I went to the corner Starbucks to get whatever. The barista was this guy who usually was their runner who comes by almost everyday and so when I held out my credit card he said, "Oh no don't worry, it's on me."

Orayt.

The next deserves a bit of explanation before I tell you about the actual event.

I work in a very affluent and high end neighborhood that has cafes with $15 dollar plates of ravioli; a predominantly white, either young and fashionable or old moneyed white haired crowd; and clothing from Paris and England. 

Anyway.

Anyway, after my lunch I took a walk outside and the valet guy Louis called me over and asked if I wanted to see someone famous. I said heck yeah and so he pointed inside the Country Mart and inside the store that sells knives for 50 bucks a pop was the lovely Tom Hanks.

I didn't get an autograph though since he was "in a rush" and he said he comes by often anyway so he could humor us "next time". Aha ha ha.

Pfft. 

Next week I'll just hang around Starbucks and I might catch Schwarzenegger glugging macchiatos with his scary-lookin' wife. 

Peace, Mrs. Terminator.


---


Tomorrow is turkey wrestling day.
 
Good luck with that, Aisha.

By popular demand, I am Vietnamese.

Them Filipinos keep telling me I am Vietnamese. Even white guys can tell I'm Filipino better than Filipinos can.

A man has been working with a clothing company in the Philippines 15 years ago and knew right off that I was Filipino. A man came up to me and after identifying me as a Filipino said, 

"Ikinagagalak kitang makilala, Aisha."

Holy crabcakes...


But mostly, everyone thinks I'm Vietnamese.

Even the Vietnamese.


---


I am going to watch "Love in the Time of Cholera" this weekend. No one is going to stop me. And it better be good or I am going to kill Mike Newell. 



For reals.
Daylight savings has screwed my body clock up real bad.

Everyday when I get home, I only have time to watch two hours of telly and if i'm lucky, get the same amount of internet time while peering over the laptop at the plasma.

Work is work is work. And man am I tired.


---


On Wednesday after running out the office early, we were stuck in traffic for two hours trying to get to the Wiltern downtown for the Regina Spektor concert. We were in such a rush that we even forgot the camera in the car and so i'm trying to retain all the friggin Spektorgenius in my brain. A guy from Only Son fronted for her and he was amazing too. So, I looked it up on youtube and there was a vid of her and the guy from Only Son doing the Hotel Song. It's not a vid of their performance at the Wiltern but hey, same diff.

After her performance the whole audience was applauding for like five minutes for an encore but Regina still didn't come out until everyone started stomping and yelling like heck for seven minutes.



And I almost lost my voice. 

 
---


I'm going shopping tomorrow to spend my paycheck. Any requests?


---


Hello weekend.

I took the bus to downtown LA today to attend a career symposium held by the Asian Professional Exchange. 

I was the youngest one there. Go figure.

They had people from a lot of companies. Networking, can't live without it. The best was that I got to talk with this lady named Laverne McKinnon who is the president of 50 Cannon Entertainment and who used to be Senior Vice-President of Drama Series Development at CBS (CSI, Shark, Criminal Minds, Numb3rs, etcetera).

Anyway, she helped me out with my resume and told me to send it to her email until we get it perfect enough so she could pass it on to a few people. 

Woohoo.

And I got a few more contacts from LA18, MTV and Wokplace Hollywood and a lot more advice on how to get into the business. So double woohoo.


----


Ok. I'm tired all the time now and from Monday to Friday, I crawl into bed by the time the clock strikes 11. I like my officemates (who are mostly guys LOL woohoo three), but it's a nine-to-six job.

I don't think I'm built for a nine-to-six job.


But I'll survive.


---


I took the bus.

For my first two days, the delicious wee amount of... drum roll please... one hundred and fifty-two dollars and seventy-four cents!

Yay.

Your fingertips across my skin
The palm trees swaying in the wind
Images
You sang me Spanish lullabies
The sweetest sadness in your eyes
Clever trick

Goodbye, my almost lover
Goodbye, my hopeless dream
I'm trying not to think about you
Can't you just let me be?
So long, my luckless romance
My back is turned on you
Should've known you'd bring me heartache
Almost lovers always do

We walked along a crowded street
You took my hand and danced with me
Images
And when you left, you kissed my lips
You told me you would never, never forget
These images

No

Well, I'd never want to see you unhappy
I thought you'd want the same for me

I cannot go to the ocean
I cannot drive the streets at night
I cannot wake up in the morning
Without you on my mind
So you're gone and I'm haunted
And I bet you are just fine

Did I make it that
Easy to walk right in and out
Of my life?


-a fine frenzy

We took a trip to the valley for some pay-per-view Pacqiao on Uncle Abe's huuuuge projection screen. We bought steaks, Uncle Sonny brought pizzas, Auntie Myrna made some ulam, Ate Akit brought the pulutan, Uncle Andre taught me how to make long island tea and I insisted on getting some salted eggs, tomatoes and eggplant. LOL.

It was so funny once the fight started, the aunties started yelling and screaming, Alexa was punching her fist in the air and shouting out, 'Pawkaw!' and Uncle Andre was cheering for Barrera. Poor Barrera, and it was his last fight too. Oh well, three cheers for the Pacman.

Inevitably later on that night, the watching turned into videoke.


Ah, the wonders of mixed drinks and family gatherings.

Another day, another interview.
 

Okay, lame segway... Bloop bloop woo...


Today was Heroes day. Waking up this morning, I was thinking more about Peter Petrelli than my corny practiced interviewee answers. But anyway, the interview went great (as usual, aha ha ha) and I apparently landed myself in a bank at the center of upper-middle class America (read: mas maraming mapuputlang tao) as opposed to where my sister works, a veritable melting pot.

But on to the more exciting stuff. We opted for the second episode of Prison Break over the pilot for Chuck (damnit) then, then... Yay!

Well, okay so I was a leetle overexcited and prolly had too high expectations for the season opener... and heck it was good but it wasn't great. And I wont even try to spoil it for you by saying, for example, that Peter is alive and has some sort of amnesia, or that say, Claire has a new cute friend who also has powers, or even that Hiro's dad dies. I will not spoil it. No sirree. 

You can't make me.

He is so much hotter than Hyuk-Joo. I didn't say more handsome because he isn't, he is cuter though. Heck, the ending was so inevitable but I don't like it. Oh sure, the gangly dancer wins over the superstar because we always root for the underdog. But! But! Rexu pronounces 'Tomorrow' like it's 'Chumoooro' and it is still so damn hot.

So I don't care what you say, he still wins.

I am so going to scavenge for Rexu's songs now. 




And here, two seconds of you melting in your seat. Enjoy.

Kanina, umulan. Malakas. Parang nasa Baguio ulit ako. O di kaya parang Milenyo ulit sa Diliman. Pero hindi. Kasi five minutes lang tumagal.

Kanina, nag-brownout. Parang nasa Baguio ulit ako. O di kaya parang Yakal kapag bumabagyo. Pero hindi. Kasi wala pang isang minuto, bumalik ang ilaw.

Kombinyent.

Happy birthday shorty. Happy birthday Jay-R. Bring on the vodka.

Tomorrow! Wentworth Miller, you'd better be hotter than last season.
Tuesday! Another day, another interview. At this rate, everyone would want me but I'd not like them.
Next Monday! The day of all days. Yatta!!
Let go of the freakin hamsters. They don't like those damn wheels and sadistic plastic boxes you put them in anyway.
Okay lang. <font size="2">Wala namang napakain si idealismo.</font>
